question: What decomposition pathway is being studied?
What method of characterization was used to determine the chemical composition of IPrAu(III)Cl-IRMOF-10?
answer: 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analysis and inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES)

question: What is the percentage of gold(III) precatalyst occupancy in IPrAu(III)Cl-bio-MOF-100?
What is the maximum percentage of gold(III) precatalyst occupancy achieved in IPrAu(III)Cl-IRMOF-10?
What is the role of TMB in the study?
answer: TMB is a trap for cationic gold(I) species.

question: What counter anion was present in IPrAu(III)-IRMOF-10 ?
Why was bio-MOF-100 chosen as a support for SXRD characterization?
answer: Bio-MOF-100 has larger pores which help mitigate steric clash, and features two symmetrically distinct BPDC moieties which allow for selective displacement of one type of BPDC

question: Why does IPrAu(III)PF6-bio-MOF-100 have low reactivity towards the cycloisomerization reaction of substrate 1?
answer: The low reactivity was attributed to a potential decrease in the rate of diffusion of nonpolar substrates through the intrinsically anionic bio-MOF-100 framework.

question: Why was TlPF6 chosen as the halide abstracting agent instead of AgSbF6 for IPrAu(III)Cl-bio-MOF-100?
answer: Treatment with AgSbF6 resulted in a decrease in crystallinity, potentially due to protonation of the BPDC linkers by HSbF6 generated from hydrolysis of AgSbF6. TlPF6 was chosen because it is less sensitive towards hydrolysis.

question: Why are defects more likely to form in IPrAu(III)Cl-IRMOF-10 when the target H2IPrAu(III)(BPDC)Cl/H2BPDC ratio is greater than 5:95?
answer: An increase in defects was attributed to steric clash in the framework between gold(III) complexes bearing bulky IPr ligands.

question: Why did efforts to access cationic gold(III) species in bio-MOF-100 through AgSbF6 treatment result in a decrease in crystallinity?
answer: This MOF degradation might be attributed to protonation of the BPDC linkers by HSbF6 generated from the hydrolysis of AgSbF6 in the presence of adventitious water.

question: Why did researchers decide to use substrate 3 over substrate 1 for IPrAu(III)PF6-bio-MOF-100 catalyzed cycloisomerization reactions?
answer: Substrate 3 has higher thermal stability than substrate 1 and can undergo cycloisomerization reactions at elevated temperatures.

question: Why was NaBarF4 ruled out as a halide-abstracting agent?
answer: NaBarF4 yielded poorly crystalline frameworks, presumably due to hard acid-hard base interactions between sodium cations and the carboxylate-based linkers.

question: IPrAu(III)Cl-IRMOF-10 was prepared via a solvent-assisted linker exchange strategy.
The architectural stabilization strategy is anticipated to be a general method for the preservation of ligand geometry.
IPrAu(III)Cl-bio-MOF-100 is a microporous material.
Reductive elimination in a rigid MOF can result in strain throughout the material.
IPrAu(III)Cl-IRMOF-10 showed a decrease in reactivity over multiple catalytic cycles.
A decrease in reactivity was observed when substrate 6 was used instead of substrate 1 in the IPrAu(III)SbF6-IRMOF-10 catalyzed cycloisomerization reaction.
The counter anion present in IPrAu(III)-bio-MOF-100 was SbF6.
